choices: a guard walks in from the dungeon door
a strange person walks in from the dungeon door
one of the other prisoners says something
one of the prisoners tries to get his attention without speaking
1.content: A drow in black plate sat in a dungeon, a prisoner of a nation. The drow's armor was like that of a Samurai, plate squares on the shoulders and pieces of place covering black leather underneath. He carried a pair of katanas at his side and a rifle on his back. This drow, Daresh, knew the power of these weapons and his own power could break through this dungeon. He sat here, waiting, knowing that he would be found to have no relation to the incident, a razing of a city, that had landed him here. The drow's ebony skin was starkly contrasted by his long straight white hair, that went down to his waist. He bore a scar across his face from below his right eye to the center of his left cheek. His red eyes were watching in the dark when...
1.title: Daresh's Induction

12.content:
The dungeon door swung open for the admittance of a strange person and five guards. This stranger only took four steps before stopping slowly, allowing the others to filter into the room behind him. A bright blue was the color of his eyes with a dark ring of brown around the edges and these first landed on the prisoners. He surveyed each one with a hint of speculation, except for the drow. Finally he nodded, a signal to the guards, and they all moved around him to the prisoners and prodded them out of their chairs and moved them across the room and out the door. All except for the drow. It was just him and the drow now, alone in the dungeon.

The stranger took his leather gloves off and adjusted his cape which was not elaborate at all. In fact, hardly anything he wore, or was adorned with, was eye-catching. All except for that amulet which hung loosely around his neck. If anyone was keen enough to spot it, they would see a green stone set in a black stone, rounded in shape. And his hair? Well, it was as dark as the shadows in that dungeon, shoulder-length and hanging free. But perhaps to a drow those shadows were not so dark.

"I am called Kaden." His gaze now fell easily on the drow. "I want to know what you were doing in Tyme?" Of course he referred to the city which had been razed and brought to ruins. By the time his men had arrived on the scene there was not much they could do to save it.
12.title: a strange person walks in from the dungeon door

choices: one of the guards enters again
121.content: "I was passing through, and of course, being a drow, I was blamed for the incident." Daresh said, sitting up so that his face was out of the shadows. His ebony skin was nothing compared to the sheer fear-inducing might of his crimson red eyes. He clearly was not afraid of this man. His weapons were laying to the side. He didn't even need them. "I truly am disappointed that even this kingdom does not live above stereotypes." he said. He leaned forward to get a better look at this man. "I had just stopped at the inn when a fire started in one of the buildings." he continued, "I ran over, hoping to put out the fire before it got too high, but found that the raiders were spreading to the rest of the town." he looked up at the moon, as if he was recounting it in the shadows of the great orb. "Never had I seen such speed performed by such a ragtag band. Orcs atop worgs moving as fast as possible." he said. "I shot down a few before the city was up in smoke." he leaned back, apparently done with what he felt like saying for now
121.title: Daresh answers

choices: escape, killing whoever is in your way
stay and continue speaking of your innocence
1211.content:
Kaden begins to speak as another guard enters the room.
"what is it? i told the guard not to interrupt me during this!"

"apologies sir Kaden..but the king aand queen need to have a word with you....about your prisoner."
"can it wait?"
"they are in the next room...i wouldn't risk it."

Kaden sighs.
"fine...i'll be right there...stay by the door.
no-one except me is allowed in here...got it?"
the guards nods and kaden exits the room.

Daresh leans against the cold stone wall...his drow ears pricking up to eavesdrop on their conversation.
"execution in the morning...."
" but sire, we have no proof it was him."
"he's a dark elf...that alone is proof enough to the people. they want justice to be done....and i am obliged to serve the people.
Have him ready by morning."

*so they plan to execute me anyways* Daresh thinks to himself.
Kaden re-enters the cell and the guard leaves.
"i have...."
"i know all about the kings decision. To be executed because i am drow."

Kaden smirks.
"figures you could hear that...so, what will you do?"
1211.title: interrupted

choices: Daresh chooses one of the three options
Daresh suggests a plan of his own to Kaden
1212.content:
There was a long moment of silence after Daresh recounted his witness of Tyme falling into destruction. Perhaps Kaden was trying to visualize the picture, considering that most of the buildings had been ruined and destroyed when his legion arrived. Or perhaps it was the word 'streotypes' that held him in such a moment of silence. ....

He glanced at the drows weapons. Kaden was no fool to underestimate the speed and dexterity of his race, and was fully aware that the prisoner could easily turn the tables on him. But Kaden had nothing to hide nor nothing to loose. He, himself, carried no weapon at all. He never found a use for weapons since he could wield magic as sharp as any swordsmaster. It was clear to Kaden that all signs pointed to the drows innocence, too. The man came on his free will as a prisoner and could have escaped at any time.

After Daresh dropped his gaze from the moon Kaden met his fierce, red eyes. “Tyme is the third city on the outskirts our kingdom that has been attacked and destroyed, and because we cannot find out who is behind this the officials are hungry to pin blame on anyone. It is unfortunate for you, being a drow, to have been in the wrong place at the wrong time. Your race is the perfect candidate to point fingers at. Innocent or not, I am afraid that my commander will judge you as guilty and set ready your date for execution.” Kaden took two steps towards the window and found the moon, yet still watched Daresh very carefully. “As I see it, you have three options which I present to you. You can stay as a prisoner and meet your trial but, as I mentioned before, I am afraid it will not fall in your favor no matter how strong the evidence stands towards your innocence. Option number two: you can skip the trial and escape.” Kaden reached out his hand and pointed at the drow’s weapons. “Nothing is stopping you from breaking out of here and I can assure you that I will not stand in your way. But understand that once you are gone I will have to sound an alarm and you will be marked as the perpetrator behind these attacks on our cities until the real identity of the attacker is revealed.” Kaden now walked away from the window and stood in front of the drow. “Option number three: you can uphold your innocence by helping us find the name of the person who is attacking our nation. I will personally walk you out of this compound and set you free to find the attacker if you agree to take one of my men with you so that he may contact me of your progress.” He studied the facial features of the drow for a split second before turning away. He walked towards the door with his back on the drow and paused, with his hand resting on the handle, “the choice is yours but I must hear it right now.”
1212.title: Kaden speaks

12121.content:
1. does he stay prisoner and wait for trial.
2. does he run off.
3. does he help find the person who started it all.
12121.title: What does Daresh do?

choices: Derrick decides to go back in and sleep some more.
Derrick goes out for a walk.
1212121.content:
Daresh gets up extremely fast, unsheathed his katanas, and sliced the mans head off. "Is that a good answer" he said aloud, as he quickly bolted out past the guards carrying the blood stained katanas.



"YAWN" said Derrick "uggh" Derick had just woken up. Derrick was the infamous bandit leader of the south who was plotting to take over a whole nation. He was a simple man he wore a leather shirt and pants, On his belt were an arrangement of daggers he could use to kill anybody, on his side in its sheath was a rare elemental sword, the sword of Fire, and on his back was his longbow and legendary fire arrows. He was about six feet tall and his face was neat and well cleaned. His hair whent down to about shoulder level and was in neat green spikes going down. He wore a headband with an unknown simbol on it. Derrick was a homunculus a being created from almost nothing and he could use nothing to regenerate. "ugg" he said slumping down "I wonder what time it is." He walked out from behind the secret cave behind the waterfall and judjing by the suns angle it was about 2:00 in the evening.

12122.content: "I could also stand trial, and if they find me guilty, escape and find the leader of the band of orcs who ravaged the town. And if innocent, I will simply go on living." Daresh said, still leaning back in the chair. He stood up and gathered his weapons, knowing the trial would come soon. He then sat back down and watched Kaden. "Any thoughts on that?" he asked.
12122.title: Daresh suggests a plan of his own to Kaden

choices: Daresh gives up his weapons and stays for the trial
121221.content:
“Well…” Kaden started to respond but heard Daresh moving, so he turned back around from facing the door to find the drow gathering up his weapons. “…if you want to hear out the sentence of your trial before escaping then so be it. Right now the other prisoners are being interrogated to get as much information out of them as possible before their execution which will take place tomorrow morning. Your trial will probably be held late tonight or very early in the morning so that they can execute you with the other prisoners. If you stay for your trial do not expect any hospitality from…

Suddenly their was a grating noise at the door and Kaden turned to find it opening up and stopping halfway to allow a man to peek into the room. When he saw Kaden the man stepped a little farther in and said, “It is the same as the other prisoners we caught at the other two cities. They will not reveal their leader. From what we can understand out of their horrible speech it is as if they do not know who sent them to destroy the cities.” The man stole a glance at the drow. “I bet you he knows who sent him. Drows are not as half stupid as orcs.” Then, the soldier saw the weapons in the prisoners hands and became alarmed. He drew out his own weapon and placed the sitting drow at his sword’s tip. “Give up your weapons you cursed swine!”

Kaden quickly brought out his hand and laid it on the upper forearm of the soldier and nudged him a few feet away from the drow so that the tip of his sword was not as close as it once was, yet was still pointed. Kaden looked at Daresh and continued what he was saying as if he was never interrupted in the first place, “…anyone, and you are going to have to play by our rules until your ‘moment’ arrives. Give your weapons to the soldier if staying for the trial is your choice.”
121221.title: Kaden responds

1212212.content: A fireball soared in through the bars of the dungeon skylight, scorching the guard to a crisp and barely missing Kaden. Moving fires seemed to snake in around the bars and form into a man wearing red robes with long brown hair. He wore a beard that wrapped around into a goatee. "Well, it seems my friend has arrived. Welcome, Meshnel." Daresh said, standing up, cutting his chains with one of his katanas, and cutting the bars. The katana he used had blue runes all over it, obviously enchanted. "Ah, Daresh, always getting into trouble." Meshnel said, melting the bars in the skylight. "Well, Kaden, I suppose I won't be standing trial after all." Daresh said, bowing towards him. Daresh's cloak glowed and unfolded into a pair of vampire wings as he flew out of the dungeon. "Oh, he's half-vampire. And I'm half-demon." Meshnel explained, his own red cloak turning into a pair of demon wings as he too flew from the dungeon.
1212212.title: Something else happens...

12122122.content:
The fireball soared through the bars of the dungeon and hit it's target, the young soldier. Kaden took a step away as the man burnt to a crisp and fell like ashes to the ground. His eyebrows furrowed in frustration at the death of one of his men but there was no time to linger on the incident. A man appeared in the same room wearing red robes and Kaden threw up a shield to prevent one of those fireballs from hitting him.

Demons were okay and so were drows, but Kaden had a personal dislike for vampires. He stood in defensive silence as they unfolded their wings and flew out of the window of the dungeon into the night sky. Kaden always knew that Daresh would eventually escape, he just didn't expect to find someone come to his aid and help him.

After they were gone the magician picked up the sword of the vanquished guard and blew the ashes off of it. If the drow was innocent for helping in the attack against Tyme, his friend Meshnel was certainly guilty for murdering one of his guards. This brought a frown on Kaden's face as he moved to the door and opened it.

The dungeon door opened to a hallway which was lit by oil lamps that illuminated the stone pathway every eight feet or so. At the end of the hallway was another door and a guard stood at this one. "Rilk," Kaden called out to this guard, "The drow prisoner has escaped. Send a message to the outpost on the outer wall of Tyme and have them assemble their archers. Tell them to shoot down anything that does not resemble a Morwhol Mount. Send another message to our sky scouts and have them try and track their trail. Also, I want to see Tanin at once." KIaden would raise an alarm throughout Tyme, just like he told Daresh he would have to do should he escape.

Rilk jerked in readiness the moment Kaden started issuing orders but hesitated to act when they were given. He stumbled in his words.."But...but sir, drows...they, they do not fly."

Kaden turned away from the guard and started walking in the opposite direction. "This one does fly." His voice could be heard by the guard, but it was more of a statement then an answer, Rilk thought.
12122122.title: Kaden leaves the dungeon

choices: Some of the pursuers find them.
121221221.content:
"You realize you didn't have to kill the guard?" Daresh said as he flew about the skies, rifle in hand.
"Yea, well, the ignorance of the guard would have gotten himself killed anyway." he responded. Archers and men on flying mounts eventually got aim on them. Daresh took the ones on the ground, firing his rifle down at the archers while Daresh fired minor fireballs at the aerial pursuers and slicing the mounts when they got too close. Once they passed the border they landed, their wings folding up into their cloaks. "How many do you think we avoided killing?" Daresh asked.
"Most if not all of them." Meshnel said. "Maybe a few mounts. I saw you aiming for the arrows and bows, are you going soft?"

"No, I just don't want to get into any more trouble than you got me into." he responded, smirking.
121221221.title: the story continues with Daresh...

1212212211.content:
Kaden turned his steps towards the stable, knowing that Rilk was swiftly carrying out his orders. The magician had not even made it halfway down the long hall of rooms when another man emerged and stopped him. This second magician was younger and taller then Kaden with short dark hair and keen eyes. He also wore the same attire that Kaden had only he was not wearing a amulet around his neck.

Kaden stopped in his tracks when the second magician met him in the hallway. He gave a slight bow of his head, as custom demanded from him, and greeted the other with a tone that betrayed none of the disrespect he felt for the man. "Greetings Bruenor."

Bruenor wasted no time with the questions he had on his mind, "What of the drow?"

"The drow escaped." Kaden replied.

At first Bruenor's expression was surprised at this sudden news, but he quickly narrowed his eyes and glared at Kaden. "How could he have possibly escaped while you were in there with him?"

Wisely Kaden did not respond and opted to stand in silence before the man, but his eyes never left his.

Bruenor growled behind his teeth in anger and stepped closer to Kaden, lowering his voice so that no one else could hear. "If it were not for that amulet of slavery you wear around your neck someone would have picked you off a long time ago and taken your rank in the Order of Onul."

Kaden's eyes narrowed, "If I did not have this stone of slavery around my neck then I would not be here at all ...in your way for power. Perhaps you can do me a favor and figure out how to remove it from me?"

There was a long moment of silence between them before Bruenor almost hissed back at him, "You know that it cannot be removed."

"Than keep your empty threats to yourself Bruenor."

The younger magician pressed his mouth closed and slowly took a step back away from Kaden.

Kaden took that as a signal that their conversation was over with and customarily he, being the magician bound in slavery, bowed to Bruenor who was a magician of freedom, and left once again for the stables.
1212212211.title: Back with Kaden...

12122122111.content:
The stable was an addition to the compound that stood three stories high. The first floor kept many horses, the second floor was used as storage space for supplies and food, and the third floor kept Morwhol Mounts. These flying creatures were rarely aggressive at all. In truth, they were very gentle and peaceful in many ways. They only had two legs that perched on large T-poles and had a very long whip-like tail that wrapped around the pole to keep its balance. Because of their very large wings and aerodynamic body build they were excellent fliers with a great ability to do almost any maneuver in the sky. Their two legs had talons but they were short and stuby and they had no front legs or arms at all. These creatures were bred in small villages and then transported to the army to be used as sky scouts. At best, someone could possible ride one of these creatures armed with a bow and arrow and attack..but very rarely would you find a Morwhol Mount, itself, engaging to attack.

It was one of these creatures that Kaden had readied by placing a saddle on its back and a bit in its mouth when Tanin reached the stables. The boy climbed up the ladder to the third floor and found its reins being placed into his hands by Kaden. The boy took the reins and wrapped them around his hand but stood there very confused.

"Now is your chance Tanin." Kaden explained, "Ride this mount and track down that drow and report back to me what you find. I will tell them that I sent you after him. Then, after a few days...disappear. The Order of Onul will think you have been killed and will forget about you. In this way you can get out of here and you can start a new life."

"But Kaden," the boy frowned, he was about fifeteen years old, "The Order of Onul is my home, I have known no other place."

Kaden raised his hands and placed them on the boys shoulders, drawing him closer so that he could have direct eye contact with him. Kaden could see the color of the boy's eyes which were the same shade of brown as his, void the bluish center. But faintly, you could almost see the same color of blue forming in the center of Tanin's eyes. Day by day Tanin's eye color was beginning to look exactly like Kadens. "If they find out what you've got then your life will be over. The Order of Onul will no longer be your home ...only a prison. You must go and escape before you mature or they will find out about you." Kaden nudged the boy closer to the Morwhol Mount, prompting him to get into the saddle. "You must hurry before that drow and his friend travels too far. This is the only excuse I can find for you to get away and fake your death."

The boy started to climb into the saddle, reluctantly.

"Make sure you report back to me a couple of times to make it look like you are truely following my commands. Do you understand boy?"

Tanin nodded his head sadly, "Yes sir."

And without another word Kaden released a rope that caused a large window to spring open. At the sight of fresh, open air the Morwhol Mount spread its wings and quickly unraveled its tale from the pole and took flight.
12122122111.title: continue

121221221111.content:
The mount was very swift in gaining speed and altitude despite all the buildings it dodged and maneuvered around. Tanin had very little experience in riding one of these creatures so he did his best just to try and stay in the saddle. While clearing the initial buildings of the city he could see archers assembled on the walls. They were all searching the skies with arrows ready.

Off in the distance he could make out some more mounts in the sky and they seemed to be circling in confusion, trying to search for the drow. As Tanin neared the outer wall of the city he saw that some of the flying creatures had been struck down, even cut in half in some places, but the riders seemed to be uninjured. He led his mount to follow the path of fallen morwhol's until there were no more to be seen and still, he flew beyond to the border of Andolsi's land.

It was at the border, when his mount was flying above the tree tops, that he spotted the drow and his friend. They had just landed with their wings folded up behind their cloaks and they seemed to be talking to each other. Tanin quickly pulled his mount out of site, flying the creature behind a dense row of tall trees, hoping that he had not been spotted.

His heart was racing now as reality of what he was doing settled in. Everything had happened so fast that he had hardly any time to register what was going on. He started to mumble and curse under his breath at the foolishness of Kaden's plan. Did Kaden not realize that Tanin barely knew how to create a contact channel with magic to relay information? He barely knew and understood the basics of wielding and weaving magic and now that he was running away from the Order of Onul ... he may never learn.
121221221111.title: continue

1212212211111.content:
"Well, nevertheless, they will send someone out for us who will eventually find us, so we had best be ready." Meshnel said, both of the two now within earshot of Tanin.
"No doubt Kaden will send a friend with troubles of his own to meet with us." Daresh said, flicking his hand at the ground where there materialized a strange structure. It was shaped and armed and made of stone and wood like a fortified castle, but was only the size of a medium-sized tent. Daresh pushed the gate open and crawled inside, Meshnel following after. The castle didn't creak or move, which suggested it was larger on the inside than the out, which was indeed the case. Inside Daresh and Meshnel were met by a scene of a castle modeled after Camelot, minus the throne in the main room. "Well, we might as well let our little eavesdropper in." Daresh said, pulling his hand out of the door, which was the same size as it was outside, strangely, and waved his hand at the general direction of Tanin, a telekinetic wave pushing him down and into the tent.
1212212211111.title: Story continues with Daresh...

12122122111112.content:
The vision of communication was almost flawless as it portrayed the person on the other end, halfway across the country of Andolsi. Not once did it flicker or waver in its creation. The voice of Onri’di Nuil was so clear that it sounded to Kaden like he was standing in the same room with him.

“You have assembled for yourself many enemies within the Order. Just yesterday I was trying to ease old Ferrin’s mind over your stubborn refusal to train or mentor someone.” His voice was deep and rough but it held a sense of smoothness that came from the many speeches Onri’di had to make throughout his official sovereignty in the Order of Onul. “Of course, no one knows our little secret that you are different from the others. It would be impossible for anyone to learn from you. So I defended you, my slave, and gave old Ferrin a book of ancient mutterings to keep his mind away from you.”

Kaden stood in the lavished room of his quarters facing the large vision. He did not say anything to his master knowing that his voice was not welcomed at the moment.

“And now I find myself having to defend you again against the accusations of Bruenor. He insists that you helped that drow escape. There is no explanation as to why the most powerful and undefeated magician in the Order was unable to stop two flying men. It took me a very long time to calm him down. ….”

“I believe the drow is innocent of relation to the attacks, master.”

“I have the Officials of Andolsi breathing down my back demanding a name of someone who is responsible. I need that drow!” Onri’di’s voice was more quick and stern this time. “Innocent or not, he will suffice!”

Kaden dropped his head and Onri’di sighed heavily trying to relax himself from a possible anger assault on his slave. “I was fortunate to have stumbled upon you when I did. My position of power and rule in this organization has come by your hand. You are also the man I trust more than anyone…more so because you are unable to lie and are always honest. But the Furian blood that runs in your veins, the very blood that gives you your enhanced powers and keeps you from lying and always speaking the truth, can be cumbersome to me at times. If it were not for your strong sense of Furian honesty you would not have let that drow escape, and I could be watching him die slowly in execution. His death would suffice the Andolsi officials long enough for us to find the person responsible… if that drow is as innocent as you believe. I have sent a party of soldiers and magicians to track down this flying drow. In the meantime I want you to move the entire legion westward towards Lysti Lake City.”

Kaden raised his head and looked at his master. He had been bound to this man for a good part of his entire life. Onri’di answered Kaden’s unspoken question, “There are rumors that Lysti Lake City is where the orcs are headed to attack next.”
12122122111112.title: Back with Kaden...

121221221111121.content:
The elven woman crinkled her nose when her horse came to a stop. She really had a dislike for these animals and would rather travel on foot but the entire entourage was moving fast, covering as much ground as possible. She had very long hair that was dark enough to be called black, but truly there were brown strands if the sun hit it just right. Her pale flesh was smooth and her green eyes sparkled with a life on their own. Her attention glanced at Bruenor who had just dismounted his horse. All the other horses could be heard breathing heavily through flared nostrils as their riders, both soldiers and magicians, tried to ease them to stand in place after running them so hard.

Bruenor walked up to one of the dogs with something in his hand and Anenfel, the elven woman whose job was to record everything that happened, looked hard to see what it was. The dogs were hideously ugly with very large pig-like noses and very small, pointed ears. They had long legs and a long slendor tail with a body covered in coarse fur. Three of the dogs were franticly sniffing for the scent they had temporarily lost and the fourth was eagerly waiting for Breunors hand. The magician uncurled his fingers to reveal some rifle shells and fired bullets that had snapped bows in half and all four dogs pressed their noses up to the objects to smell them again.

Anenfel had never seen such objects before. She had heard that the weapon the drow used was rare in Andolsi and only the weapons master could explain what they were. She didn’t have to wait long before the dogs had raised their heads to the sky and caught the scent again. The breed of these dogs were renowned for their incredible tracking abilities and their tails stood straight up as they bounded off towards the border.

Bruenor jumped into the saddle of his horse and kicked it to speed while waving for everyone to follow fast. He cursed under his breath for having to be out here tracking this drow down. This should have been Kaden’s job for it was the old fool who let the prisoner escape to begin with. Slave or no slave, Kaden was favored by Onri’di. But it was of little matter that Kaden got to move to Lysti Lake City and fight orcs while he had to tromp through the forest and find a drow because Bruenor was looking forward to executing the dark elf part vampire himself.
121221221111121.title: continue

1212212211111211.content:
The vision flickered and then blinked out of existence and Tanin gritted his teeth. Stupid…dumb…stuff! He walked back over to where the Morwhol Mount was. He had sent a message to Kaden of the whereabouts of the drow but he wasn’t sure if it got through or not. His vision’s hardly worked no matter how much he practiced on casting the spell and creating it. He checked the rope that he had tied to a limb to keep the mount from flying off and said, “Might as well get a closer look at these guys since we will be leaving in the next day or so for our own adventures.”

Tanin left the mount tied up and he walked towards the direction where he had last seen them. Trying not to be seen he sneaked between tree trunks and bushes until he found them. While bending low behind a thick berry bush he watched them crawl into a castle-like-tent and he muttered to himself, “What the….? I thought I had seen it all when Kit flashed her breasts at me but this even beats that.” He commented on the small castle and how two full grown men could fit inside of it.

When both Daresh and Meshnel were inside Tanin stepped out of his hiding place and tiptoed closer to the structure that had appeared from nowhere. Curiously he got close enough to extend a hand and touch it, but just as his fingertip was about to poke one of its walls he suddenly found himself falling. Or wait, he wasn’t falling! Was he being pushed down or was he growing smaller? Either way he found himself being pushed through the door of the mini castle and inside its structure. His eyes were wide from surprise and fear at what was happening and the first thing he saw after being telekinetically pushed through its door was the two men. He jumped backwards and stared at them… kinda speechless. This was not supposed to happen.

“Umm…” he glanced from Daresh to Meshnel and back again at Daresh. “….hi?”
1212212211111211.title: continue

choices: back with either Kaden or the search party.
12122122111112111.content: "You really need to learn how to react better to magic. But then again, that was a spell to rival Merlin himself." Daresh said. "Welcome to our enchanted castle. Smaller on the outside than it is on the inside. But i assure you, the cannons on the walls are just as strong as full-sized cannons. This tiny castle could defend against an army, and has done so in the past." Meshnel looked Tanin over. "You look to be an apprentice mage." he said, "and from what i could garner from my magical senses you aren't very good at magical communication."
12122122111112111.title: back with Daresh

121221221111121111.content:
Despite the calm and casual tone in Daresh’s voice, Tanin tensed up even more when he discovered that they knew about his attempt in creating a vision for communication. He wondered if they knew that he sent their location to Kaden. If they did, he would probably not live to see another day.

He started searching the surroundings of the castle with his eyes, wondering if there was a way out to escape, while he answered with carefully chosen words. “It seems the area is not favorable for the spell. Bad magical reception.” Tanin was more then a little nervous. Although he could tell white lies and skirt around the truth, Furians were unable to lie if asked a direct question.

His gaze found its way back on Daresh and he gave him a weak smile, “Nice place.” Perhaps he could prolong his death by talking to them. “Sooo…if the castle is magic, does that make the cannons and cannon balls of a magical or man-made material?”
121221221111121111.title: Tanin replies

1212212211111211111.content:
It was nearing dusk when the dogs began to get overly excited. They ran faster, bellowed louder, and shivered in anticipation of meeting the prey. The search party became more cautious as their horses covered the ground swiftly, especially since they had crossed the border of Andolsi and were in someone else’s territory.

When the small castle was finally spotted by the men, the dogs had already circled it about twenty times trying to find a hole to get into it. Bruenor allowed no one else to go near it. Instead he stopped the search party a distance away and watched the dogs bellow and bark their presence.

As Bruenor gazed at the structure from a distance he overheard a common soldier strike up whispered conversation with some other comrade. “That must be the entrance to a underground fort. It is too small for two winged men to get in.”

“No.” The voice of a female, Anenfel, answered back. “They are inside of it. It is a magic castle.”

“That is not magic! There is no such thing as a spell that makes tiny castles. It must be sorcery.” A young magician piped in.

Anenfel rolled her eyes. “Just because they do not teach you a spell in the Order for tiny castles does not mean the magical spell does not exist, you moron.”

“Hush!” Bruenor commanded strictly from everyone. Aside from Kaden, he was also unbeaten and unmatched in his power. The only difference between Kaden and Bruenor was that he was a free man and Kaden was not. By unwavering rules, slaves and freemen were not allowed to challenge each other for rank in the Order of Onul. Bruenor would inherit the sovereignty of the Order not from birthright, but from his extraordinary magical talent and his free status when Onri’di Nuil passed away.

There were about thirty soldiers and twenty magicians included in this search party and they all sat on horses. Bruenor turned around to his men and was quick to give his orders. He dispersed them out in a circle around the enchanted castle so that it was surrounded. But he made sure they were of a great distance, a distance out of cannon range away. He mixed magicians with soldiers so that the magicians could aid the soldiers in attack and defense if needed. And making sure that everyone was dismounted and on their feet, he had the horses tethered in three groups and ordered for everyone to wait.

And so wait they did,… not desiring to send a message to those the enchanted castle occupied nor desiring to start an attack right away. Bruenor and his party just waited. What were they waiting for? Well, he would know it when he saw it.
1212212211111211111.title: Bruenor and the Search Party

12122122111112111111.content: "Are you just bad with your magic, or just bad with lies?" Meshnel asked Tanin. Daresh poked his head back out of the castle and shouted. "Yes, this is a magic spell, one I devised myself, and you'd better back up farther if you don't want to be struck, these cannons fire longer than normal ones! Trying to dispel the castle won't work either!" he ducked his head back in before anyone could try anything.
12122122111112111111.title: Daresh and Meshnel

121221221111121111112.content:
Tanin opened his mouth as if he was going to say something in defense but was cut short when Daresh suddenly moved his attention elsewhere. The drow stuck his head out the door and started hollering. Tanin was confused at first until he realized who the drow was yelling at. The boy blinked a few times in quick, deep thought. Because Tanin had been pushed in such a big hurry, he had missed out on a lot of activity in the Order. He had no idea that Bruenor was leading a search party and that Kaden was moving the entire league to Lysti Lake City. He could only resolve that the Order had received his message and had teleported a search party to this location. That was the only explanation for how they got here so fast.

Tanin’s eyes narrowed on the drow in a newfound anger. Teleportation was only reserved for the most dire situations the Order was involved in because it cost extreme amounts of energy and time. It seemed to the boy that this drow must have been heavily involved in the attacks on Andolsi for the Order to have put so much energy in capturing him again.

When Daresh ducked his head back in Tanin wasted no time giving him a piece of his mind. “I may be bad with magic, but at least I don’t use what little I know to raid villages and cities! I don’t go around killing children, women, and men who are just trying to make a living out of life! And I certainly do not use my magic to make alliances with orcs so they can do the dirty work for me. I don’t know what kind of power trip you receive from destroying and burning cities but I do know that it takes one low scumbag to do it!” Without knowing, Tanin’s hands were balled up in fists from the amounts of anger he was trying to keep under control.
121221221111121111112.title: Tanin replies

1212212211111211111121.content: Daresh did not lash out, or kill him, he only smiled. "If you truly believe that of me, then prove it. have I killed anyone? Nay, only split their weapons. Meshnel simply jumped the gun with the scorching of the guard. Not even Kaden finds me responsible for the attacks. I was just in the village at the time of the attack, and even though I killed several of the orcs, they saw a drow and judged it as the culprit. And your message failed. They most likely sent a search party because their flying troops could not catch me."
1212212211111211111121.title: Daresh and Meshnel

12122122111112111111211.content:
Tanin had no reason to believe anything Daresh had just said. But one could tell that he was disoriented in what exactly to believe and who to trust. Kaden, who might as well be his father, kept on telling him that the Order was not a good place for him to be. When on the other hand the Order has done nothing but took care of him and teach him how to use his magical talent. It was hard for Tanin to see Kaden’s view, and obeyed his wishes only because he knew the man thought it best and has never steered him wrong before. Why would this drow speak about Kaden the way he did and why did he not kill anyone else when he could have? Unanswered questions faced Tanin….

….but he still held true to his argument when he replied back to Daresh. His tone much more calm in the respect that Daresh could have lashed out at him. “I do not have to prove anything that I believe.”

Suddenly there was a loud noise from above the castle, outside. It sounded like a large explosion with pebbled rain in its wake. They could feel the ground tremble under their feet and Tanin thought at first that the ceiling was going to fall. His knees bent and he cowered only before he discovered that the castle held strong and steady against the attack.
12122122111112111111211.title: Tanin replies

121221221111121111112111.content:
The night had matured and Bruenor’s sign that he had been looking for was clear in the starry skies. He started his attack against the castle, trying to break it down by launching a spell. All the magicians were involved, meditating and chanting to pull it off. Tiny earth fragments floated up from the ground with an arcane, blue glow surrounding them. Tons of them floated up above the castle until they met directly above and accumulated into a large ball. This ball grew until its circumference was about the size of a large wagon wheel and just before it launched downwards onto the ceiling of the castle it was ignited with a fire that burned blue. To Anenfel, it looked like a giant comet that fell onto the castle and exploded, sending its shard fragments in all directions. There was a one minute interval between each attack from the giant comets because it took so long collecting the material to create the large rock, even with all magicians helping.

Anenfel recorded everything she saw. From a mental concentration her magic allowed her to scroll the events down onto a journal that currently sat in the capital of Andolsi. It took a very well, seasoned journalist to do this and there were only a few of them in Andolsi. In this journal she recorded their search, the discovery of his castle/fort, the way Bruenor started the attack, and even the Morwhol Mount they found tethered up nearby.
121221221111121111112111.title: Bruenor and Anenfel

1212212211111211111121111.content:
The figure could harldy be seen in the shadows of the moon. A dark robe covered his entire body and a heavy hood concealed his face. A gentle breeze pushed some dead leaves across the ground where a giant slash formed into existence. It spread open to reveal a perfect oval, a rift in space, and out of it stepped a giant orc. When the creature was clear the teleportation spell quickly vanished like it had never happened.

From the looks of his heavy armor and deadly weapons, and the way he stood proud, one could tell he was a leader. His size was very intimidating and muscles covered every inch of his body. The orc slightly lifted his chin and regarded the person who wrapped himself in dark robes. “My men…executed.” The orc said in the unlearned language. “you didn’t stop it.”

“Such is the price of battles my friend.” The concealed man answered, “It would have created an outrage if I would have voiced against the executions. I cannot afford any chances on my identity being revealed. Besides, you let your men tear down those sculptures in Tyme that I had asked you to spare. It is a pity you had to do that…I really loved those statues.”

The orc shifted his foot and side glanced. “Sculptures look the same…. as walls.”

“Well, we will put the matter behind us. It is important that we make strong our alliance so that our goals are accomplished. I am holding true to our bargain and will give you what you desire, when my desire is reached first.” The hooded figure stepped forward once in eagerness of his next words, “there is an Andolsi army defending Lysti Lake City my friend. Do you think you can destroy it?”

The orc snapped his body into professionalsim, almost offended that he was asked such a question. “We will crush bones…and walls…and kill, destroy!”

A smirk formed on the face of the dark man. “Good.”

The teleportation portal opened back up behind the orc, showering the creature with its light and catching his attention. Taking the cue, the creature turned around to enter it once again so that it could teleport him to his orcish army and move them against Lysti Lake City.

Only when the portal vanished once again, and another gentle breeze graced across the ground, did the robed figure address another creature who had been hiding in the branches of a tree. “The orcs will succeed against Lysti Lake only because of their numbers. But for sure, they will win. Then, we move onto our bigger plans…”

The hidden creature jumped from its place in the tree, unfolded its wings to catch a break, and landed on the ground without a single sound. It was a demon, and its red eyes pierced into the darkness of the hood that covered the mans face. “We need a cover-up.”

“Go and visit our drow then and see if you can persuade him to join. Whether he does join or not, he will still suffice our plans.”
1212212211111211111121111.title: The Orcs

12122122111112111111211111.content: "That little comet spell? Please, this castle has withstood the hellfire of several Baalrogs before. A comet is nothing." Daresh said. "Well, if they can cast that, they're not far enough away." he flicked his hands up into the air, and the cannons outside aligned with the chunks of rock lifting up into the air. They fired, and the cannon balls, made of a strange, spiked metal that looked like magic itself had taken form, grew to the size of a normal cannon ball. They were propelled by a fireball, and exploded on contact with the rocks, sending pieces of stone everywhere. The cannons automatically homed in on magical presences, which would be the spells used on the stone. It would not hone on the Magi because Daresh had specifically removed that from its possible targets for this part. "Good luck making another comet if you can't get the stone into the air." he said, smirking. "Now then, would you like to contact Kaden?" he asked, turning to Tanin
12122122111112111111211111.title: Daresh and Meshnel

121221221111121111112111112.content:
When the cannons started to fire, and when the pieces of rock failed to create the comet, Bruenor changed his method of attack. Now that the cannons were seen on the walls he had all the magicians attack with one of the most basic spells, a fireball. They released their fireballs, three at a time in a direct row, against the cannons. The fireballs were lined up one after the other so that if the cannon honed in on a fireball and dispelled it, there would be another fireball directly behind it streaking in for a hit.

Arrows from the soldiers were ignited with real fire, not magical fire, and shot against the tent as well. Some of the castle was made from wood, so perhaps while the cannons were busy on deflecting magical fireballs, they could burn it down from the shots of regular arrows.

Atop his horse Bruenor watched carefully, seeing how effective this new attack would prove to be. Anenfel now sat on top of her horse as well, next to Bruenor and her expression was a little confused. After a while she voiced one of her thoughts out loud towards him, “I wonder why those cannons are not shooting on the men. I have seen many chances where a cannon had a clear shot at them.”

Bruenor looked at the elven lady and scowled. “Just go back to writing in your journal sweetheart. Leave the questions for me.”
121221221111121111112111112.title: Bruenor

1212212211111211111121111121.content:
Tanin gave Daresh a nod. Contacting Kaden was not such a bad idea. Afterall, it was Kaden that got him into this mess in the first place.

He had already been made fun of by the half drow and half demon about his ability to channel a vision so this time he was a little more then determined to not goof up. He took a deep sigh and closed his eyes, trying to block out all the commotion from the scene outside. He was deftly aware of Daresh moving to take care of the new methods of attack against the tent because he started to whisper some chanting words. These words were a driving force to the magical manna in the world and when he spoke them the magic began to obey and weave into a spell, all invisible to the naked eye. It wasn’t long at all before an oval materialized into reality and Kaden’s face appeared. Tanin smiled, proud to find that the vision was clear and unwavering in its creation. Almost perfect.

Kaden smiled too. “There you are. You have gotten better at that vision spell.” Kaden’s voice was clear and if one didn’t know better it could sound like he was standing in the same room with all of them.

“Yeah well…” Tanin replied, stealing a glance at Daresh who had finished doing whatever he needed to do to keep the attack at bay, but then looked back at the vision, “People always said I work well under pressure.”

“What pressure?” Kaden probed.

Tanin gave a nod in the general direction of Daresh. He also answered gravely, while rotating the vision around so that Kaden could see the two men. “I think the drow wants to say something to you.”

Kaden was a bit surprised to find Daresh but he quickly checked it and frowned. “Tanin, you’re an idiot.”

The boy rolled his eyes.

Still looking at Daresh and Meshnel the senior magician heavily sighed. It did not take him long to consider the situation that Tanin was in. Concern fell on Kaden’s face and he asked the drow, “what do you intend to do with the boy?”
1212212211111211111121111121.title: Tanin and Kaden

12122122111112111111211111211.content: "Well, for now, keeping him from being killed by keeping him in this castle. You have heard, perhaps, of the miniature castle of Brellen? I have made my own modifications to the castle." He said, placing his hand on the walls and ordering the cannons to improve their aim. The cannons shot directly through the first two fireballs and exploded on the third. The flaming arrows stop, extinguished, and fell a few inches from the castle's walls, like it had a barrier preventing physical attack. "Those poor fools. They have never seen this kind of spell before, and thus will never be able to even strike the castle."
12122122111112111111211111211.title: Daresh and Meshnel

121221221111121111112111112111.content:
Kaden nodded at Daresh and replied. “Good. I hate to see someone falsely accused for an offense they did not make and I apologize for the search party. But some things are just out of my hands and I have no control over them. It is fortunate that you know your magic, otherwise Bruenor would be having a field day with you. Maybe some time in the future, when all this madness dies away, we can sit down together and relax. Perhaps I could exchange something with you and you could show me your modifications to the Brellen castle.”

“Wait a minute!” Tanin jumped in, rotating the vision so that he could see Kaden’s face. “You mean to tell me that you believe this drow is innocent?”

“Yes,” Kaden answered Tanin. “That is what I believe.”

“How so?”

“A lot of factors.” But Kaden realized that his short answer did not satisfy the young boy, so he continued and offered one of those said factors - a very obvious one. “It just seems unlikely that a person would go to such extreme effort to not kill anyone if he was standing in league with the orcs.”

Tanin dropped his head and closed his eyes, “but why did you send me out here to track his location if you thought him innocent?”

Kaden’s expression became hard, but his tone did not detect it. “You forget the main reason why I sent you on your own path….” He let his sentence trail off, allowing the boy to pick up on the indications of what he was talking about.

Tanin raised his head slowly and looked back at Kaden. He could see his blue eyes clearly and knew that his own eyes were changing to the exact same color. It would only be a matter of time before there would be no indication of the original brown hue that Tanin’s eyes possessed. He could also read Kaden’s face and saw that the man was worried about him. The senior magician took upon himself the responsibility for caring about the boy, and Tanin appreciated it very much. “No, I did not forget.” He answered quietly.

Kaden took a slow breath and returned to the original conversation, “If I were you I would not make Daresh your enemy.”

After a moment of thinking the apprentice replied. “I have always trusted you with my life Kaden and I have always stood by what you have said and believed. I am not going to stop doing that.” Then, Tanin turned his gaze on Daresh. “I will fight for your innocence if you will have me on your side?”
121221221111121111112111112111.title: Tanin/Kaden

1212212211111211111121111121111.content: "We could very well use you. And worry not Kaden, I'll make sure he gets efficient magical and combat training from Meshnel and I. Not only will he perfect his magical arts but he will learn the ways of the weapon, if he is willing to try." Daresh said, looking at him. "Ahem, Daresh? Perhaps we should use that old failsafe for when we can't get out of an onslaught." Meshnel said, stepping up. "Ah, yes. Well, Kaden, I'm afraid we'll lose contact with you for a few minutes, but once we are secure again, the connection will re-establish." The ground around the castle seemed to swirl and Kaden's connection fizzled out. The ground shattered under the castle and it fell through a swirling purple vortex which closed after they fell through. The portal opened up several miles into the wilderness, and the connection reopened again. "Ah, there we go. Karuf's great vortex always works to get us out.
1212212211111211111121111121111.title: Daresh and Meshnel

12122122111112111111211111211112.content:
A soldier ran up to where Bruenor and Anenfel sat on their horses.

“The fireballs are not working because those cannons just blast through them taking three at a time. The arrows…” He took a few deep breaths “…they are just falling like sticks to the ground.”

Anenfel regarded Bruenor for a second. She had been quiet since he had called her ‘sweetheart’ only because it had made her angry. She thought it wise to bite her tongue then to say anything smart-like. Only now did she speak up… “Maybe we should try speaking to them.”

Bruenor scoffed. “You think they will just let u…..”

But his words were cut short when there was a sudden shift in the magic of the land. He could feel the stress of magic being manipulated and pulled into the earth until it cracked underneath the castle. There was a whole lot of trembling in the ground and men stopped their arrows and fireballs to watch in stupor as the castle fell into a purple vortex and disappeared.

Silence ensued the scene from until it was clear that they were gone.

“I was expecting it to fly away…” the soldier who had delivered the news about the effectiveness of their attack broke the silence with his words.

Anenfel shook her head, still looking hard upon the vortex whole that had covered back up when the castle disappeared. “No, we could have tracked it with the dogs if it flew away. …Now we have no way of knowing where it went.”

Bruenor frowned and checked his horse into attention by pulling up on the reins. “Gather the company. We depart in 10 minutes.”

“Where are we going?” Anenfel asked the magician as he started to walk his horse away.

But Bruenor never answered.
12122122111112111111211111211112.title: Bruenor

121221221111121111112111112111121.content:
Tanin turned his eyes onto Daresh after looking outside a small slotted window in the wall of the castle. “That was impressive. Can it fly, too?”

Kaden’s voice could be heard from the vision that had quickly collected itself from the juggle of the vortex. Even though he was not there in person he knew what had just happened. Tanin’s question was ignored because Kaden started to speak. “I now have less to worry about knowing that the boy is with you Daresh. I owe you one. Although most of his magic will come naturally when he matures into a Furian, he could learn a lot of viable skills from you and Meshnel. Especially in the field of weaponry.” Kaden could see the expression on Tanin’s face lighten with life when the subject of weapons came up. The boy would be more then willing to learn from Daresh and Meshnel, both magical and fighting skills. “My league has finally arrived in Lysti Lake City to defend it against a rumor of orcish attacks. If you find or discover any clues as to who is leading these orcs then please contact me as soon as possible. If there is nothing else to discuss then I will take my departure from this vision?”

Kaden lingered in the vision, waiting to see if there was anything else the drow would like to say before he left.
121221221111121111112111112111121.title: Kaden and Tanin

1212212211111211111121111121111211.content: "The leader of the raid group wears large obsidian armor and carries a greatsword. He has a large scar across his face from above his right eye to the left side of his top lip. If you find him, do whatever you can to him, but make sure it is severe. Minor injuries mean nothing to him. I had to almost cleave his arm off for him to flinch." Daresh said. "That's all I have to say." he said, waving his hand over the image, it fizzling and disappearing. "Alright. Meshnel will teach you how to use a sword single-handedly. After you finish that, if you wish, I will teach you to use twin blades, and perhaps a gun." Daresh said. Meshnel stepped up, holding a steel longsword in his hands for Kaden.
1212212211111211111121111121111211.title: Daresh and Meshnel

12122122111112111111211111211112111.content:
The vision cleared away and Kaden turned from it to survey the medium sized city of Lysti. From where he stood on the balcony of a building in the mayors house he could see the great lake bordering the city on its east. To the north was a dense forest that touched the base of the cursed mountain range called Moloch Mountains. Beyond the south and west sides of the city was the great plain of Andolsi - a savannah of tall grass that covered much of the country. Lysti Lake City was another city on the edges of Andolsi, it’s main income was trade that came from boats that traveled from the ocean, up Lysti river and into the great Lysti lake. Kaden suspected that the orcs, if there was going to be any, would attack the city from the north.

“Magi Kaden Derrevere.”

Kaden broke his gaze off of the view and found the mayor bowing slightly in respect.

“It is a great honor to have your company in my city. With the army of Andolsi within its borders I am confident that we can withstand anything.” The mayor straightened up and made eye contact. This man was old in age with silver hair and wearing a long robe of gold. “I apologize that our barracks are not big enough to house all of your men.”

“The men will erect their own tents Mayor. It is no trouble at all.” Kaden responded with a smile.

The mayor walked up beside the magician and looked out over his city. “That much fog in our sky has never been seen before. It has got my people very suspicious and nervous. They say that the other three cities of Andolsi witnessed a sky of fog before the orcs came and destroyed them.”

“We will defend your city with our lives, mayor.”

A boy ran onto the balcony with a red face…it was clear he was out of breath. “We have lost contact with the NorthPoint Outpost. We cannot bring anyone up in a vision.”

The Mayor frowned. “The NorthPoint Outpost is the furthest most base before the Moloch Mountains begin.”

Kaden nodded. “I will gather my company and visit the Outpost myself.”
12122122111112111111211111211112111.title: Tanin/Kaden

121221221111121111112111112111121111.content:
Tanin was swinging that longsword around, very awkwardly. At one point he lost balance in a swing and the sword, which seemed a little heavy to him, fell from its angle and clanked its tip on the stone floor. He held the hilt in both hands and catching his breath he said to Meshnel, “I always thought that weaponry ….would be easier…to learn then spells. Now I am not too sure.”

They had been practicing for about an hour and the workout was strenuous on Tanin. He lifted the sword back up from the ground and held it out like he was going to attack Meshnel.

But suddenly something appeared right in front of his face out of nowhere. It was a hideous face with red eyes that glowed with fire and a snarling mouth that showed pointed teeth. Tanin yelled, truly freaked out, and dropped the sword like it was the cause of the vision. His eyes were wide with fear and he looked around to try and find what he had just saw.

“Did you see that?! Meshnel…Daresh…did you see it?!” He swerved around, stepping over the sword, and tried to find what he had just seen. That step was miscalculated though and his ankle got caught on the hilt and he tripped and fell to the ground.

There was a ripple of laughter that echoed in the room and a deamon materialized enough to show itself before everyone. It was very tall and thin with black, leathery skin. It almost looked like a human except its arms were abnormally long with fingers that ended in sharp points. Its face was human except for the mouth of pointed teeth and its eyes, that burned with depths of fire, was the most intimidating of all. It was a spiritual deamon and it stood there for a moment and watched Daresh and Meshnel very accurately when its amusement with Tanin was over.

Spiritual deamons differed from other demons. This particular deamon was caught and bound in the spiritual realm and was never allowed to pass the barrier into the real world. If one would strike at it with a weapon the weapon would fall straight through as if the creature was never even there. They worked differently from the demons that lived in the materialistic world also. They were the creatures in the stories when you heard about someone being possessed by the devil. They were after your soul and were masters in the fields of manipulation, persuasion, intimidation, coercion, and seduction. Spiritual deamons played and attacked your mind…never the physical body. If they found one tiny piece of your mind that bent to their will then they would latch on like a leech and stay until that person was entirely possessed by them. Most times people were attacked by spiritual deamons without ever seeing them at all. It was those thoughts of suicide, anger, murder and the likes that were the weapons of these creatures.

And so this deamon showed itself before the three men. Because of its inability to touch the realistic world it was truly no threat to their lives at all and, if it found no foothold on their minds, it would no doubt leave.

The words came into Daresh’s mind telepathically from the deamon. “I was sent to deliver a message…” Its eyes seemed like it could delve into the depths of Daresh’s soul. It waited for the drow’s response, too.
121221221111121111112111112111121111.title: The Deamon

1212212211111211111121111121111211111.content: "Then give it." Daresh said. His mind was surrounded by barriers stronger than those of this castle. The demon couldn't even touch his mind beyond sending messages, and if he tried to force his way in his own mind would be shattered. The same was true for Meshnel.
1212212211111211111121111121111211111.title: Daresh and Meshnel

12122122111112111111211111211112111111.content:
By an innate ability the deamon could see the barriers surrounding the drow’s mind and it smirked. Even if the creature was after possessing his mind this would not be the right time. Spiritual deamons were precise creatures and only attacked when the timing was right. It was not after the drow’s mind, or soul, but was after something else instead.

“We would make it worth your trouble if you would join us in our plans.” The telepathic message came once again to Daresh. The other two men, Meshnel and Tanin could not hear anything. “We know how to reward our friends.”

The deamon began to move in the air, circling Meshnel and then coming up in front of Tanin where it paused. Its words still directed towards Daresh, and him alone. “These two friends of yours do not even have to know that you have joined our efforts. It can be our little secret. A secret that you will be greatly rewarded for if you keep it.”

The deamon then turned its back on Tanin and looked directly at Daresh again.

Tanin pounced upon the opportunity. He had previously gotten up from where he had tripped on the floor and had picked up that sword he had been practicing with. Swinging a hefty swing he slashed the edge of that sword across the deamons back, only to find it hit nothing and fall through in an unexpectant clank to the ground. Tanin blinked.

The deamon did not even acknowledge the boy and his attempt.

“The person I represent will give you whatever is in his power to give. All you have to do is lead the orcs into battle.”
12122122111112111111211111211112111111.title: The Daemon

121221221111121111112111112111121111111.content: "Begone..." he said, and his eyes flashed, and enough spiritual power to shatter the demon's form like glass erupted out from him at the demon. The demon was either to leave or be near killed if not obliterated. "I do not work with orcs who got me into this reputation. Or malicious orcs in general." he said, Meshnel nodding. He walked across the castle foyer like nothing had even happened.
121221221111121111112111112111121111111.title: Daresh and Meshnel

1212212211111211111121111121111211111111.content: The daemon screamed, a soul-shattering scream that Tanin and Meshnel had to cover their ears for, but Daresh simply stood through. It shattered like glass, the pieces vanishing into thin air. "My reply is given." Daresh said calmly, striding across the room to a cabinet, where he pulled out an amulet. "While practice is the best way to learn to wield a weapon, there are other methods." Daresh said, pondering the use of the amulet, which stored the knowledge of how to use a single blade.
1212212211111211111121111121111211111111.title: The daemon

choices: a guard enters and harasses you
13.content:
Daresh knew he had 3 other cellmates...he had almost excellent vision in the dark.
The one to his left was a old man.

The one to his right was a young lad. What he did to be in here Daresh could only guess.
It was the third that had captivated his attention.

The man looked like a beggar, but his stance said otherwise.
He sat against the wall...back arched and senses aware.

Daresh spoke first.
"what have they put you here for?"
The man stayed silent.

"I know you can hear me."
"of course i can...it's ignoring you that's the hard part."
the man's sharp tongue slashed Daresh.

The man scooted himself off the wall and into some light so Daresh could see him better.
He was a half elf!
His hair was blue and went down little past his shoulders, golden eyes, muscles rippled across his body, and his right eye was covered by a deep scar.
His left leg was also broken.

"Who are you and what happened to you?"
"My name is amatheus. I was at the final battle of Arthane plains. My enemy, a gold armored elf, slashed me across the eye. When i fell, she stomped on my leg, breaking it. After i passed out, I woke up here...for what they will not say."

Daresh spoke.
"We are both here unjustly. If you are able, I can help you escape. Otherwise, we can stay here and leave our lives to chance.
I leave the choice to you."
13.title: greetings

choices: the interrogator lave to question amatheus.
Daresh breaks out and rescues amatheus
134.content:
Before either man could speak, the prison door flew open and a fearsome sight stood there.
The interrogator stood there.

Tall.
Covered in thick black clothing.
bulging muscles.
Eyes dark as the night.

He descended the stairs as the half elf skidded back into the shadows.
"don't bother amatheus....i know where you are..."
six guards entered the room behind him.
"three of these guardsmen will transfer you to my chambers...where i shall have fun torturing you."

" but i know nothing....i have said nothing but the truth!"
"it matters not...i only follow orders....take him!"

Three guards unchain amatheus and drag him from the cell..screaming.
"and now, me and my friends here get to have our fun with you....Daresh."

Daresh looks at them with smug eyes.
"if you think you can harm me....then go ahead and try.
I promise it will be little in comparison to what i do to you."
134.title: pain beyond compare

info.brief_description: We go through the stories of many fighters as they go about their lives
info.description:
We go through the stories of many fighters as they intertwine, fight, romance, grow, etc. Add your own character to this story as we go.

Either,
1: Put in your own bio for your character as you introduce them
2: Place a link to where we can learn more about this character
3: Put the character in detail.

-You can control a different character's actions if you are acting for the moment, however, you CANNOT act out of character, as in a hardened warrior running from a single guard. If your action requires an immediate response then you can control them.

-No killing a character without the owner's permission

-Mythological creatures can be used, but be sure to only use the facts that that mythology gives on them, do not modify them for your own uses.

-A self-created character must have some kind of story. be prepared to explain it if needed.
